item.title: 1-to-1 Correspondence in Game Controls
item.description:
Video: Super Pole Riders - How We Got Full Pole Control

Here’s Bennett Foddy talking at GDC about having a 1-to-1 correspondence between the controller and the in-game feedback.

Game feel is often discussed in subjective and almost “handwavey” terms(e.g. “It feels good.”), so it’s really helpful to have someone examine it from a very specific and precise perspective.

In particular, having players self-enforcing the 1-to-1 correspondence and that weird elbow trick were really clever.

Read also: This crazy long deconstruction of game feel by Tim Rogers.

item.title: Feedback for Swipe Input
item.description:
I tried this game Heatos on my phone the other day, which involved swiping tiles around on a grid.

The tiles only moved after you’ve completed a swipe.

Threes handles swipe input really well. The moment you start a swipe, the tiles move a little. You can slide your thumb or finger back and forth until you’ve decided to commit to a move, and the tiles will move in corresponding fashion. Beyond providing feedback, it doubles as a preview of your intended action.

Even when tiles can’t be moved, there’s a subtle stretch and squash effect to indicate so.

The point is, there’s feedback throughout the entire duration of a swipe, not just at the end.
